comments.commentBody: Very different reaction here.  The theme is built around three 17s, each with an R at both ends (not in the grid), and each crossing the 9-letter central reveal at the middle letter.  That's pretty good right there.  Then you have 7x4 corners, nearly forced by the theme answers (the only alternative would have added a ton of 3-letter answers) -- and fill is darned good (ASTR and possibly ILSE the exception).  You might see a bit more sparkle in a themeless, but this is a themed puzzle, after all.  I think Sean is off to a strong start.  I liked this one a lot.

This wasn't Obama's personal security team!!!   The many  various news articles have made that they clear, so leave Obama out of this!!!  (And I'm not a Obama fan, just someone who wants to stick to the facts!)

Uh, no, we're talking about people who enthusiastically supported Obama in 2008, and no longer support him in 2012, due to his right-wing policy agenda.

Not the type of people who would have voted for McCain in 2008.

And you think I'm the one who's tripping.

Who, tell me, has compromised us in the years leading up to April 18, 2012? Who has stalemated Americans at every opportunityt? Who sets up the horrible situations which lead to no regulations? Who left the country to reduce expenses and make a higher profit? Who has been firing people and shutting down business for the goal that the CEO's and Executives will continue to receive their extreme bonuses for their role in it? Americans need to talk back to big business corporations and the wealthy rich who get tax breaks that they don't need because, get this, they are hoarding the money, it doesn't trickle down, it trickles up, up, up and they knew it would. Such saps we have been in America's middle class. And, then they blame it on President Obama.
What's Romney's "sterling record of accomplishment," say, over the last six years? Clipping coupons and competing for the GOP nomination? How sterling. How vacant. How presumptuous of you AND him.

Mr. Spergl,

In point of fact, the Founders deemed that 'mob rule', or direct democracy with the involvement of all the people, was too destructive to their new nation.

As a result, they elected to use a system of representative democracy, where the representative was to use his "mature judgement" to enact legislation, but was not to "sacrifice it to [the constituents'] opinion", as it would be a "betrayal".*

*Quotations taken from Edmund Burke, a major influence on the Founders.
Uh, SS are not household or executive staff.  I'd be pretty concerned if the POTUS were responsible for professionally managing this team, of all things.

Instead of the batting cages after work, to destress, I spend some time on the Fox News blogs, debunking the many fairy tales and fantasies issued forth there, like so much virtual effluvia.

Mike's post sounds like one of more literate Fox posters: convinced their personal, anecdotal experience is actually the pulse of the nation. The constant obscene, adolescent, incredibly offensive things said about anyone who dares to have an opinion slightly different than the raw meat thrown to the Fox faithful is beyond endemic: it's SOP.

These are people who openly wish the Secret Service walks off the job, and allows the President to be killed. These are people who genuinely think the President is a communist, while illustrating from their posts that they have little understanding of communism. These are people who insist liberals "hate America." These are people who make simian references to the Obama children, and consider themselves patriots for doing so. These are people who do not understand the first thing about the legal system, yet insist they "respect the Constitution."

My concern about America is a simple, and IMO, growing lack of intellect. The vote of an educated, thoughtful person, who has decided upon a candidate by careful reason is worth the same as a vote from a barely literate, rage-filled Fox viewer whose opinions are provided by others.

Sometimes, the thought of living on a small island miles offshore seems incredibly inviting.

Obama is incredibly divisive! The day after Ted Nugent called for NRA members to consider shooting the president, you call Obama divisive. Weeks after Rush Limbaugh blatantly slandered a perfectly innocent women who he disagreed with, you say Obama is divisive. The Republican Right has honed using politics of wedge issues to a fine (I would call it an "evil") art for the past 20 years.
Preposterous.  This poster knows absolutely nothing about how the Secret Service is supposed to run.  Obama has NOTHING to do with this scandal.

Any Hispanic who votes for  the Republicans is a fool. The Republic position is that all Hispanics are assumed to be illegals unless they can prove otherwise --- in other wprds, if you're Hispanic be sure to keep your up-to-date passport with you at all times just in case someone in authority demands to see your papers. Sounds vaguely threatening, doesn't it? Like something out of an old WWII movie. Well that's what we're coming to.

It is an indictment of the quality of education in our nation when an intellectual elite can make grand predictions based on demographic data of a few variables. Having never done the numbers as these people have I would like to believe they have confused correlation with causality which is a common issue in social sciences.

I don't want to believe political policy is sold like soap flakes and branding overcomes self interest. It would suit my biases better to think that people who want the best for the nation rely on solid arguments rather than appealing to emotion. It would make me feel no better to see the politics of inclusion to adopt the selling of America. Policy should be based on right and wrong not appealing commercials.

What a bunch of hyperbolic crap.  Insinuating the Secret(e) Service in its entirety has no respect for the Obama "regime."  And their drunken behavior reflects a well thought out and reasoned assessment of the character of the President.  Boy, you are REACHING for evidence of your hatred of President Obama.  One of the worse arguments I have ever read.
You think prowess, charm, and wit can negate the need to pay for a high class escort you meet the first time for a one night stand? Uh ... okay, I suppose if you're a celebrity or your name is Bond.

In response to magoo, the definition of integrity and honor varies depending on who sets the bar and who enforces its virtue. By layman's standards, there's no question that the agents acted inappropriately (they got caught) and should be reprimanded accordingly. But neither does she deserve special treatment because of what happened. She asks for an amount of money from one trick that is equal to or greater than what most people earn in a week! Yet you suggest giving her an education and another job. Where is your integrity and honor?

I had a friend carjacked and kidnapped in Brazil, with the police clearly having been in on that scam as well, so let's not be so naive about the nature of some of these 'businesses'.

If I'm giving him the benefit of the doubt then I potentially feel sorry for the poor guy, who tried to stand up to that extortion, got scammed nevertheless, and then got in trouble with a massive scandal over the matter. Clearly he should be held to the same standard that all the rest of us abide by and should never every have sex!...

Sex happens, shocking! Prostitution happens legally, shocking! Human nature happens, shocking!

No wonder she plans to leave Cartagena, now that her notoriety there has disrupted the scam she was running...

Once we start firing the folks who squander our reputation and our dollars like the GSA people and othe government employees on OUR payroll.. this horrible behavior will stop.. SHAMEFUL and DISGUSTING.

Per one article, the unofficial moto of the SS when travelling by plane is:

"Wheels up, rings off."

So, let's see;
- travel away from home and family
- time off
- alcohol
- legal prostitution

Where is that going to lead? Why be surprised?

If this were British, French, German, Italian ... security personnel there wouldn't be much fuss at all.

One error with this piece: Obama won Loudoun County, Virginia in 2008. A seemingly small issue, yes, but it's been one of the fastest growing places in the U.S. in the last 30 years, is now the #1 county in the country in per-capita income, typifies the outer-suburb boom during these decades ... and now it's one of the swing counties in an increasingly significant swing state.

http://www.cnn.com/ELECTION/2008/results/county/#val=VAP00p8

And it wasn't just Obama. Loudoun had been solidly GOP up until Mark Warner's and Tim Kaine's victories for Virginia governor, followed by Jim Webb's win for US Senate. The trend in Virginia for the last decade has been that 9 of the 10 most populous jurisdictions and 9 of the 10 fastest growing jurisdictions (by total numbers, not by percentage) have been voting Democratic in statewide races.

The key, really = Virginia's been getting more dense. The exurbs (Loudoun's neighbor Fauquier County, e.g.) still vote GOP, but as a locality in a major metro area moves from exurb to suburb, it starts to get more purple.

.

You cannot draw any conclusions from 2004.

Senator Kerry would have been President if he ran his campaign differently. That is the only lesson.

A huge shame that he did not.

.

To Tim P:
"NYC murder is the lowest in the nation"- NYC deserves credit for coming down from the highs of the 1970's but it is not the lowest - St Paul, San Diego, Seattle, Honolulu, San Francisco, Portland, Denver are lower to name a few.

"Population is the highest it has ever been" - that is true for almost every city. There are very few actually losing population. What counts is the population growth rate. Over the past decade the US population grew 9.7% while NYC grew 2.1%. Boston grew 4.8%. Dallas, Houston and Atlanta grew at a rate ten times that of NYC.

To Michael in Los Angeles:
NYC is not more important than Boston, it's just bigger. NYC has per capita income of 22,113 Boston, 23, 353; NYC has 27% with college degrees, Boston has 38%; NYC has 18.5% of families in poverty, Boston has 15.3%.

Hello,
The financial meltdown came about because of deregulation of the banking industry - not enough capitalization in the banks which caused their over lending and bundling of derivatives to make them go bust. Everyone paid for the meltdown except the banks who were bailed out. The banks hate the government until they need it. Note few banks said no to taking government money. That is the ultimate hypocrisy to me.
Like the excess regulation that caused the mortgage debacle?
Ignorance is bliss.

Finally, the Democrats who were responsible for bringing about this economic crisis through excess regulation are about to be defeated. May Romney win and bring and to these excess Demorcratic induced deficits!

How short are people's memories?  Wariness over the economy an opening for the very Republican Party that got us into this mess big-time, and then used every tactic in the book to frustrate the recovery?  If Americans really feel that way and vote accordingly, they will deserve what they get.  Too bad it will hurt the rest of us.

he knows better how to run a successful enterprise and what's involved...which is a darn sight better than our president (who i voted for) does imo. if your primary concern is the economy and our disastrous deficit, the choice is clear...and it is not the president. on other issues, far from clear...

Dc1.  Romney knows how to destroy businesses and transfer those assets into his own pocket.  If that is how you are defining successful-heaven help the American worker.  It will be your job, your healthcare and retirement benefits he will be pocketing.

DC1- the thing people don't realize is that private equity doesn't 'manage' anything. They buy companies and hire other people to manage them. I wager Willard has never managed a business unit in his entire life. Note that the Olympics were an event - not an ongoing concern.
Who really thinks Romney has a clue about middle-class peoples personal finances? come on lets not lie to ourselves or our readers NY Times...
